title: Probing lipid interactions of plasma membrane proteins: a micropatterning approach

author: Gergo Fulop, Institute of Applied Physics

segmentation: Hi everyone, first of all I would like to thank the organizers that I got the opportunity to present my work here.
Ann is probably most of you already know in the mammalian plasma membrane we have thousands of lipid thousands of different lipids and proteins with different local and temporal heterogeneity.
But the fundamental mechanisms of how, when and why they interact with each other mostly remain unanswered.

So since the investigation of different different lipid phases in the plasma membrane, it is Val thought that in a moment mammalian cell membrane we have a liquid ordered phase which form certain size domains and these areas are typically enriched in sterile xans finger myelin.
And there is also another phase, the liquid disordered phase which is rich in unsaturated fatty acids.
So if you think about also proteins in this system.
You can appreciate.
That there are certain points.
Translational modifications of the proteins which may change the behavior of the protein in regards of these faces.

So for example, if we think about population as an action, the protein gets palmitic acid tails in the membrane and this protein may change its partitioning from the liquid disordered phase to the liquid ordered phase.
So if one wants to work with the system, there are certain limitations and problems.
Of course, with any other research.

So first of all, most of these experiments about the lipid faces were done in model systems such as bilayers and giant unilamellar vesicles, but results in live cell membranes are rather controversial.
Another problem is the size of these domains.
Since these are roughly 10 or 100 nanometer domains in the plasma membrane.
So in order to investigate this.
His domains we have to have very good microscopes and and techniques to see them like super resolution for example.
And also if you want to label a lipids then we may run into the issue.
That's the behavior of the lipid is completely different from the original molecule.
If it has a huge die on top of it.
So in my research project, my aim was to concentrate on the the population of a transmembrane protein and to recruit these proteins with a technique called micropatterning.
In life cell membranes.
And if we have these proteins recruited in the membrane, which probably induced formation of liquid ordered or disordered phase, then we want.
To probe these domains with different lipids and proteins in the membrane.
So first of all, I would like to talk about the technique micropatterning with which we recruited these proteins in the life cell membrane.
When we do micropatterning, the main aim is to offer a surface to the cells which has patterned antibodies on top of it.
So if we offer this surface to the cell and they grow on them, then probably the proteins will be patterned in the in the Summer Bay.
So.
The the steps of the Micropatterning is the following.
First of all we put a streptavidin drop on top of PDM S stamp.
We call it and after drying we transferred the streptavidin pattern on top of glass substrate.
And after passivation of this substrate with fibronectin, we can basically attach any kind of antibodies biting elated antibodies to destructive eating pattern.
And if the cell is growing on these, these patches of antibodies, we can recruit special transmembrane proteins or proteins in the cell membrane.
So.
If you have a micropattern cell, we can do single molecule diffusion analysis on lipid probes or.
Protein probes here you can see again a micropattern cells from as a cross section an.

Now if we look at this cell from the top here you can see a turf image of of very cell and I depicted for you here that if you look at this area is exactly these recruited proteins in the cell membrane.
What you can see here in the microscopic image.
So the first step in my experiment is always to take an image of of these cells.
Where are the patterns?
How good is the micropatterning?
And as a second step I add.
Lipids or protein probes to the system and they get incorporated in the membrane.
And then I want to track the mobility of these molecules in the in the cell membrane.
So here you see the recruited proteins again.
This we usually call this.
This domain isn't on area and next week we have the off area where there is a not so many proteins recruited.
And then we can check the mobility of the tracer molecule and very important information for us is how is the diffusion of these probes at this on area and outside of the patterns or at the off area.
So here I I show you what kind of molecules an obstacle molecules and tracer molecules we chose in in this experiment.
So we chose a transmembrane protein called hemagglutinin in which by default has four population sites and we also have.
Department latest version of this protein so it's a mutant version where there is zero palmitoylation site at the protein.

So these were the transmembrane proteins which we used in the cells and we recruited them in our experiments here and then when we added the tracer molecules, I chose certain liquid ordered phase pros such as cholesterol, sphingomyelin and GPI anchored protein CD 59.
And also we had a liquid disordered face probe such as DOP which has unsaturated fatty acid chains in the intermembrane.

So after we have all these ideas, we started to think what can actually happen between a tracer, an obstacle molecule, and we came up with certain ideas such as starrick hindrance, which is the the most apparent one.
Since if we have crowding effect in the cell membrane than these probes can feel certain certain starrick hindrance by the recruited proteins.
Also there may be specific binding, so maybe there is an interaction.
Between the probe and the obstacle, but it can easily happen that actually this transmembrane protein has annual lipid forming around them.
So in order to find out which scenario is valid.

My colleague did some simulations to see what results we can expect and if you look at these graphs on the Y axis, what we usually plot is a quotient of the diffusion diffusion coefficient of on the on area.
So the probe is diffusing here inside where the proteins are recruited divided by the diffusion constant.
Outside of this area.
So basically this quotient should be one if there is no effect.

If if the probe can freely diffuse in this area, just as it would do outside of this area, and as we go towards higher densities, so when we have the crowding effect, this number should be lower than one, meaning that the protein is slowing down in this area.

What is very important from these simulations that if we do the same fitting to our data, actually we can calculate the size the diameter of the tracer molecule and the obstacle molecule so we can get an actual number.
How big are these proteins or how how big they appear with this analysis system?
So.
If you look at the results.
First, I depicted here cholesterol.
When I measure the diffusion of cholesterol with two different cell lines, the first airline was with a hammer.
Gluten in with palmitoylation sites and the the mutant cells which didn't have any palmitoylation sites.
And what you should appreciate here that we didn't see big difference between diffusion behavior of cholesterol.
If we had palmitoylated or non populated proteins.
We did exactly the same experiments with a GPI anchored protein.
It should be again a liquid ordered phase probe and as you can see, is exactly the same kind of behavior.
We have a bit of slowing down effect, but there is no huge difference between the population deficient cell line and Y type cell line.
Also, I I put it here, some numbers for you.
So when we calculated the size of the obstacle molecule plus the tracer.
For the population deficient cell line, we got this number 9.2 nanometer and for the wild type cell line it was 7.8.
So it's it's quite similar and if you look at the the city 59 protein and the obstacle, this number is mostly the same so.
After this experiment, I also wanted to try liquid disordered face probe and for that we used the OPE.
With the same label on top of it, KK 114 and doing the same experiments, you can see that here again we got a bit of slowing down effect and the number is actually very very similar.
What we got with cholesterol, so these numbers are.
Rather similar this year it was 7.8.
Yes.

So after this, actually we wanted to try other lipid tracers as well and we used single mile in with an auto die on top of it and with this tracer actually we got also a quite low number and the same effect but it was not that significant as with the other lipid probes.
So to put these numbers and read.
Is in the in a table?
What we depicted here is the case when you have palmitoylated protein AGM, GFP and a Department.
Elated and again you can see that there is no big difference between CD 59 and and cholesterol and.
What is most probable?
What happens here that actually there is a stearic hindrance between?
And the probe molecule and the obstacle.
Also, we wanted to rule out that there is a specific binding, maybe between cholesterol and the the.
the Hamilton Inn and the OPI.
So I really wanted to try to different lipids which have very different partitioning behavior.
And as you can see the same, we got very similar numbers, so we could somehow rule out that there would be a specific interaction between the recruited protein.
And the tracer.
I'm talking about single mailing.
We are not entirely sure if this is Terry Kindreds or maybe an your lipid formation binding.

So in order to find out that we are currently working on some more experiments with more tracer molecules with exactly the same kind of dye and hopefully we will get a clearer picture what's going on here.
But what I can?
Say for sure is that population of AGM GF did not have a significant effect on cholesterol and city.
59 diffusion and also comparing collateral and EOP.
They they show very similar diffusion behavior.
An abide they have different membrane partitioning.
Also in order to find out what's going on with single mailing, we are planning to do more experiments with the OPC Andy SPC.
We should be more likely to partition into the liquid.
At the end of my talk, I would like to say thank you to my supervisor and my colleagues who always supported me, and of course to our funding agencies and for your attention.
Thank you very much.
